I like your idea, but I think having different level of mobs could get complicated. The different higher level mobs should also drop a greater amount of loot as killing them should give a higher reward. The mobs would most likely come with a complicated spawn algorithm. I like the idea of implementing a skill tree, and I believe, one could upgrade skills by spending experience points on the different types of skills being given. Some examples of these skills could be adding more overall health to the player, or adding a longer sprint before losing hunger on the hunger bar. Other types of skills could also be climbing, longer breath under water, faster sprint speed, higher attack damage, higher jump, and many other possibilities.

There's already zero incentive to kill pandas. Why punish people who do? They drop bamboo which is one of the easiest to farm recourses ever. You're getting worked up over a non-issue.

Besides how many kids do you think will see this and then go "ah yes I will now fly out to china and kill pandas." The reason they changed parrots is because parrots are a semi-common pet and children could actually very easily feed their pet parrot chocolate. Children can't hop on a plane and go big game hunting.
Villagers will as I understand it get angry with you if you kill a panda in front of them, and you do not get any loot for killing pandas either.

I don't really like this idea. I like the concept of achievements actually effecting the game, but Minecraft is not reality. Minecraft is like another world only reachable by computer or console. It's like a land of magic waiting to be discovered. I think this would be a good Mod/Addon idea, but not a new feature for the main game.

@Wolftopia

I wouldn't be against more treasure items. I'd certainly prefer them to the current loot tables.

And I agree, I was kind of shoehorning a use for gold in there. I don't think we need to have too many reagents though - maybe just removing the gold slot and making the reagent optional (which it already is) would be fine.

Thanks for the feedback!

I'm all for using themed ingredients for making more predictable enchantments. I believe two new slots is too much. It should be Lapis and one additional item, like the Beacon. Your list of ingredients is spot-on. Gold should become useful with through a durability buff.

100% love the enchanting reagents; basically encompasses what I suggested https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360043245252-Enchantment-Accessability-Arcane-Focus- here- glad to see others are on the same page.

But as others have said, two slots are a bit much. Just one extra slot for the optional reagent (Between the book & lapis) is enough and reduces complexity. Just have gold give access to certain enchants, like flame and fire protection.
It would also be nice if at least Packed Ice &/or Blue Ice was unclimbable for spiders for mob farms as well.
Perhaps the player must be looking above the horizon to be able to drink, and the player would hold the potion to look like they’re drinking.

I will explain what Mobius762 means more in depth.

1. Create a map

2. Place the map in the center of the crafting table GUI.

3. Place paper in all the other slots.

4. Ta-da!

It is very much a necessary feature in mobile, where you can only control two things at once.  If you don't like auto-jump, you can disable it in your settings.
Just turn it off

It's a toggleable feature.
Remove it.

Maybe make the auto-jump setting stay working after playing an older version of mc? It's really annoying when changing from a version of mc with no auto-jump (like 1.8), then to have to re-enable it when I start playing a newer version (like 1.14.4). Yeah ik the thing about "we can't change the past" but for future versions maybe a different file to store new settings in and a better management system to deal with settings that didn't use to exist.

Please no....  I get that it's realistic, but it would also be a pain.  Especially if you accidentally fall a long distance, barely survive, are surrounded by mobs, AND you have slowness, nausea, weakness, and mining fatigue.  It turns that scary accidental fall while caving into a near-guaranteed death.
I like the idea of a mild slowness but the rest is just too extreme.
Just give the player a slowness effect when he takes 5 or more fall damage but then lower the amount of fall damage taken from heights to balance it out

I hope what they do is allow a technicial system that goes faster than the ice, rather than nerf the new ice.  Although, given that they have continued to patch all the travel methods that technical players have come up with, it seems like they don’t want fast technical travel to be a thing...

Then they turn around and give us boats on ice and it's super fast.

Has anyone determined if blue ice makes "2-high jump-sprint travel" faster than packed ice? If the travel is exactly the same but still "ridiculously fast" and "on par enough compared to piston bolt", then you could say just using packed ice makes it much less expensive.

I'll assume you've never tried to make a blue ice transport system in survival. It's not easy, fast, or cheap in any way. This is a fine alternative for people who don't want to spend endless hours learning and building finicky redstone machines. They can instead spend *more* endless hours trying to farm ice in a way that's legitimate in survival.

A "world exporter" feature would be a great addition. This would allow players to export their worlds regardless of the selected “File storage type” (Application or External).
I would like to EXPORT and IMPORT worlds DIRECTLY from the game! Also save to the cloud, with OneDrive, since we use a Microsoft account.

In fact, that is something already available on Minecraft: Education Edition. See Support Center Home > Learn to play -> Game Features > Cloud Upload and Download and Support Center Home > Learn to play > Teaching With Minecraft > Import, Export, and Manage Worlds

I hope they revert it and I hope they don't give it the copper bulb treatment where they just don't care about the negative feedback. Yeah, it worked as intended, so they didn't have any reason to change it.
It doesn't even affect anyone negatively; removing the feature will though, not keeping it. I really hope someone higher up the ranks sees this and understands for once.

Just to let you know Minecraft will eventually add the mobs that lost the mob vote they are just put into the library ideas and will be added when the right time comes along. There should also be terrain blending.

The underlying idea of having an official way of resetting chunks between major versions is desirable and I vote +1 accordingly. OPs proposed method is however impractical as it results in too great an inconsistency in regards to what chunks get reset (while exploring you may remove a shrub here, blow up a creeper there, and mine ore or chop trees willy-nilly, resulting in a swiss cheese of interacted with chunks), all while adding extra game checks while playing that will unnecessarily slow the game down for little gain to most. The lost FPS may not be much, but the checks might apply to quite a number of player actions and will potentially add up quite a bit on a server with many players.

If an official chunk reset tool is to be added then it should not be any less flexible than current community alternatives and preferably separate from the regular gameplay. This could be a standalone gamemode that lets you load a save as a chunk map (I'd imagine it to be similar to how you view the in-game maps) where the displayed world map shows the saved chunks (e.g. those explored) which can be selected and reset if desired. Being able to get a full view of the world you've explored through this gamemode would also be useful otherwise and not just for resetting chunks.
